Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story:
I sit at the kitchen table, headset on, laptop open, my partner across from me, eyes red and voice trembling. They just got off a call with their boss, and now they’re looking at me, searching for reassurance, for the kind of support only I can give. “I don’t know what to do,” they whisper, and I want to reach out, to hold their hand, to listen and help them sort through the mess.

But my screen blinks—another call. I click accept, and a customer’s voice fills my ear, launching into a barrage of technical questions about the new service. The script in front of me is useless; I fumble for answers, trying to sound confident, while my partner’s gaze pleads for my attention. My manager expects me to handle every objection, to keep the customer engaged, but my heart aches for my partner, who needs me now more than ever.

I feel split in two, pulled by the demands of my job and the needs of the person I love. My voice wavers as I try to juggle both, the pressure mounting, unsure which role to choose in this moment.
